diagrams.description: Environmental engineering's foundations emerged in the 19th century with public health concerns driving sanitation improvements and the first water treatment plants (London, 1829). The early 1900s brought chlorination for water disinfection (1908) and sewage treatment plant development. The 1940s-50s witnessed industrial pollution concerns rising and early air quality regulations. The 1960s marked a pivotal decade with Rachel Carson's Silent Spring (1962) raising environmental awareness and major legislation beginning. The 1970s saw landmark environmental laws: Clean Air Act (1970), Clean Water Act (1972), Safe Drinking Water Act (1974), and EPA establishment (1970). The 1980s addressed hazardous waste with RCRA and Superfund (CERCLA) legislation, plus advanced treatment technologies development. The 1990s brought sustainability concepts, life cycle assessment methodologies, and green chemistry principles. The 2000s advanced with membrane technology improvements, advanced oxidation processes, and climate change considerations. The 2010s-2020s continue with circular economy principles, microplastics research, PFAS treatment technologies, green infrastructure, carbon capture systems, and nature-based solutions becoming mainstream approaches.

timeline
    title: The History of Environmental Engineering
    section: 19th Century - The Sanitary Revolution
        1842: Edwin Chadwick's "Sanitary Report" in London
        1854: John Snow links cholera to contaminated water in London
        Late 1800s: Development of water and wastewater treatment plants
    section: Early-to-Mid 20th Century - Air Pollution
        1930: Meuse Valley fog in Belgium
        1948: Donora smog in Pennsylvania
        1952: The Great Smog of London
        1955: Air Pollution Control Act in the U.S.
    section: Late 20th Century - The Modern Environmental Movement
        1962: Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring"
        1970: The first Earth Day
        1970: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is established
        1980: The Superfund Act (CERCLA)
    section: 21st Century - Sustainability and Climate Change
        1997: The Kyoto Protocol
        2000s: Focus on renewable energy and sustainable design
        2015: The Paris Agreement
